statement.p: A few winters ago, it was very cold in northern Washington, and Jessie thought about leaving the kitchen faucet running overnight (so the water pipes wouldn't freeze). Jessie's roommate Kayden was a little concerned that they would be wasting a lot of water, so they performed an experiment.

Kayden turned the kitchen faucet on so it was dripping water at a constant rate. Then he held up a single teaspoon under the faucet, and it filled in \displaystyle{12} seconds. So, the water was "flowing" at a rate of \displaystyle{1} teaspoon per \displaystyle{12} seconds.
Question: They were going to sleep and planned to get up \displaystyle{6} hours later to turn off the faucet. How many gallons of water would have gone down the drain in that time?
Answer this question by converting \displaystyle{6} hours into gallons. Give your answer as a decimal number, rounded correctly to the nearest thousandth of a gallon.
In all, approximately gallons of water will flow down the drain in \displaystyle{6} hours.
